p: Acclimation ability and thermal tolerance are key traits in physiological ecology and could play an important role in shaping the geographic ranges of species (Bozinovic et al., 2011; Calosi et al., 2008; Spicer & Gaston, 1999; Sunday et al., 2011). If acclimation ability is correlated with environmental thermal variability, then species experiencing broader thermal variation (i.e., wide‐ranging species) should have a greater capacity for thermal acclimation (Brattstrom, 1968; Feder, 1978). Results of our MCMCglmm analyses indicate such an association, where wide‐ranging species of temperate salamanders are found to have a greater propensity for thermal acclimation than narrow‐ranging species.
